content: MADRID--Spanish renewable energy and engineering firm Abengoa SA said it had reached a restructuring deal with its creditors to avoid Spain's largest-ever bankruptcy, sending shares up nearly 4% in mid-morning trading in Madrid. A group of investors including Centerbridge Partners LP, Elliott Management Corp. and Oaktree Capital Management LP have agreed to inject EUR1.17 billion ($1.31 billion) into the debt-laden company, Abengoa said in a regulatory filing on Thursday. Abengoa will also receive EUR307 million in financial guarantees, the filing said. In exchange, investors and creditor banks, such as Spanish lenders Banco Santander SA and Banco Popular Español SA, are set to own between 90% and 95% of Abengoa, depending on whether it meets certain targets. The company didn't clarify whether 75% of creditors had agreed to the restructuring deal, as required by Spanish bankruptcy law. Abengoa said it plans to hold a telephone conference with investors and analysts on Aug. 16 at noon New York time to provide further details.
title: Abengoa reaches deal to avoid bankruptcy

content: Getty Images Shares of auto retailers took a beating Monday following a profit warning by Lithia Motors, less than two weeks after Warren Buffett sparked a broad rally by buying into the sector. Lithia Motors’ stock LAD, +1.41%  tumbled 17% in midday trading to a six-month low, after the eighth-biggest auto dealer cut its third- and fourth-quarter earnings outlooks, as declining used vehicle values weighed on profit margins, and offset an upbeat sales environment. Among shares of other auto dealers, those of sector leader AutoNation AN, +2.03%  slumped over 5.8% to an eight-month low. Asbury Automotive Group’s stock ABG, +2.97%  shed as much as 8.6% to hit a five-month low early in the session, before bouncing slightly to be down 4% in midday trade. All the above stocks jumped on Oct. 2, and extended gains on Oct. 3, after Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway said it was buying Van Tuyl Group, the largest privately-held U.S. auto dealer. At that time, Buffett said he expected to buy more dealerships over time. He now has the chance to do so, at a nice discount, as all the above stocks fell Monday below where they were prior to getting the Buffett boost. content: LONDON--Tanzania-focused miner African Barrick Gold (AGB.LN) Friday reported an 8% increase in first-half gold production and said it swung to a pretax profit. First-half gold production of 346,581 ounces was 13% higher than a year earlier, while gold sales of 330,947 ounces were 5% higher. The London-based company posted a pretax profit of $62.2 million, having posted a $857.3 million loss a year earlier when it took a hefty impairment charge on one of its mines. Revenue fell to $445.5 million from $487.4 million. The "all-in sustaining cost" of production came to $1,118 per ounce sold, 25% lower than the first half of last year, the company said, hailing the success of operational improvements. "We are pleased to report strong results for [the first half], with increased production and continued cost discipline enabling the business to return to cash generation," said Brad Gordon, chief executive officer. The miner said it now expects to produce 700,000 ounces of gold this year, up from guidance of 650,000-690,000 ounces issued in April, as new projects have begun to contribute to production. It also confirmed its cost forecasts. Write to Ed Ballard at ed.ballard@wsj.com Subscribe to WSJ: http://online.wsj.com?mod=djnwires

content: TORONTO-- Barrick Gold Corp. said Monday it will place about 41 million shares of its African Barrick Gold PLC subsidiary with institutional investors as it continues to streamline through cost cutting and asset sales. Toronto-based Barrick said the 41 million shares represent about 10% of London-listed African Barrick, Tanzania's largest gold miner, and about 13.5% of the parent's holdings in the company. The Canadian gold giant said the offering will be made through an accelerated book-build offering process to be launched immediately. The offering has yet to be priced. Barrick Gold last month posted a worse-than-expected fourth-quarter loss, slashed reserves and forecast for lower output this year. The company, which like many large miners bought pricey assets at the top of the commodity cycle, has been working to make itself into a learner gold producer by shedding noncore assets and cutting costs. It sold its jointly owned Marigold mine in Nevada last month. That deal followed the sale of three Australian mines and its energy business last year. African Barrick too has been hit hard by lower gold prices and high operating costs. It posted a net loss last year on high impairment charges. content: Moody's Investors Service upgraded automotive retailers Group 1 Automotive Inc. GPI, +3.01% and Sonic Automotive Inc. SAH, +4.41% a notch each Wednesday, and increased the prospect of an upgrade for another, Asbury Automotive Group Inc. ABG, +2.97% because of improved operating performance. The firm upgraded Group 1 to Ba3, which is three notches below investment grade and the highest rating among the three companies in Wednesday's ratings actions. Moody's said the company's better operating results in the last few quarters have strengthened credit metrics. Analyst Charlie O'Shea noted Group 1 has largely maintained cost savings it implemented in late 2008, which has resulted in higher earnings and thus improved leverage. "In addition, Group 1 has obtained new revolving and floorplan facilities, with the 2016 maturities improving its financial flexibility," he said. The rating has a stable outlook, as Moody's believes Group 1 would continue to manage its cost structure to preserve the resiliency of its operating performance even in the event of a downturn. Separately, Moody's raised its rating on Sonic a notch to B1, which is four steps below investment grade, because of its improved credit profile resulting from its better operating performance. "Sonic continues to generate solid traction from its favorable brand mix, and has largely avoided most of the issues with respect to the Japanese manufacturers that have occurred during 2011," O'Shea said. He said Sonic continues to reduce debt and improve earnings. The rating has a stable outlook, reflecting the ratings company's belief that its brand mix will continue to resonate with consumers and that Sonic will continue to manage its expenses prudently, which--like Group 1--would likely keep credit metrics in balance even in a downturn. For Asbury, Moody's raised its outlook on the company to positive from stable, while it affirmed its B2 rating, which is five steps below investment grade. O'Shea noted that Asbury's debt-protection measures have improved because of its better operating performance but said the challenge for the company is now to improve its interest coverage. He also said Asbury could experience additional positive ratings momentum if it successfully replaces or renews its revolving credit facilities with a looming August expiration. Shares in all three company's were down in recent trading. Group 1 shares were down 1.2% at $37.74, Sonic shares fell 4.2% to $11.36 and Asbury shares were 2.1% lower at $17.44. content: -First half net profit up 21%; doubles interim dividend -Reaffirms annual gold output, cost guidance -Expects cash costs to fall after rising 24% on year in first half (adds details and updates share price) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Anglo-Tanzanian miner African Barrick Gold PLC (ABG.LN) Tuesday said first half net profit rose 21% and reaffirmed plans to meet its annual cost and production targets despite suffering setbacks in the second quarter. The FTSE-100 miner will to double its interim dividend to 3.2 U.S. cents a share after reporting record cash margins, due in part to surging spot gold prices. "Looking ahead, we are confident the business is well positioned to continue delivering strong results over the second half of 2011 as we start to see the benefits of the operational improvements we have made at Buzwagi, the continued delivery from our other three mines and ongoing progress on our portfolio of growth projects," Greg Hawkins, African Barrick Gold's chief executive said in a statement. First half revenue rose 30% on year to $446 million and contributed to a 25% on year rise in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization or Ebitda to $196 million and net profit attributable to shareholders of $120 million. The gold miner boosted its profitability despite a 3% decline in first half gold output to 356,208 troy ounces by achieving a 26% on year rise in average gold sale prices and through gold inventory management. African Barrick Gold expects production to rise in the second half following a challenging first half operating environment in which it suffered an illegal attack on its North Mara mine and a SAG mill motor failure at its Buzwagi mine. African Barrick Gold is still targeting 700,000 to 760,000 ounces of gold output in 2011. It expects to lower its annual cash cost to $590/oz to $650/oz in 2011 from $655/oz in the first half as output ramps up in the second half. First half cash costs rose 24% on the year as a result of cost inflation and mine sequencing at North Mara. The company has also become more reliant on back-up diesel power generators as Tanzania's hydro-reliant power grid suffers due to East Africa's severe drought. Hawkins said he was not concerned about initial Tanzanian government rumblings over a windfall tax on mining companies since the company's tax agreements at its four operating mines in Tanzania--Bulyanhulu, Buzwagi, North Mara and Tulawaka--are legally binding. Furthermore the company has a good working relationship with the government to determine an economically viable tax structure for future projects, he added. African Barrick Gold has $455 million of cash on hand and is still considering mergers and acquisitions in West and Northeast Africa, Hawkins said. It also expects to finalize the details of a secondary listing on the Dar es Salaam Stock Exchange within the next few weeks, the company's head of investor relations Andrew Wray said. At 1149 GMT, African Barrick Gold's shares were up 21.40 pence or 4.4% at 210.50p.
title: African Barrick Gold affirms targets, ups dividend

content: The scramble for smart-grid technology to monitor, measure and better manage electricity, water, and traffic is gathering place. Take Schneider Electric's EUR1.4-billion ($2 billion) acquisition of Madrid-based, Nasdaq-listed specialist software company Telvent. Schneider is overpaying. But the French energy-management specialist is sticking to a stated goal of bite-sized acquisitions after flirting with a high-risk transformational deal earlier this year. Schneider has offered $40 a share in cash for Telvent, 40%-held by Spanish industrial group Abengoa which is tendering its shares. At a 16% premium to Tuesday's closing price, the Telvent offer is not cheap. At 12 times forecast 2011 Ebitda, it is paying less than the 20 times Ebitda ABB paid for Ventyx last year. But taxed and capitalized, estimated cost savings of $13 million a year are worth less than $100 million - not enough to cover the $210 million premium. To make the numbers stack up, Schneider is counting on boosting Telvent's $1-billion sales, currently 40% from transport and a third from Spain, with revenue gains of up to $40 million by 2016. The potential is there. Schneider, a leading maker of devices and sensors which measure electricity flows for utilities, factories and buildings, is profiting from a world of rising electricity demand, rapid urbanization, and tightening environmental standards. It also supplies software to control and protect power networks and maximize their efficient use. Telvent has developed software to pull that data together for utilities among other customers. Systems integration might account for $46 billion of the $120-billion market for upgrading power grids in the U.S. and Europe, according to Bernstein. True, the transaction is small in the context of Schneider's EUR20-billion annual sales. Still, having scared investors in April with a $30-billion approach, since abandoned, to security and fire-protection company Tyco International, Chief Executive Jean-Pascal Tricoire needed to reassure them he's not letting an A-grade credit rating go to his head. Acquisition risk helps explain why Schneider's shares have treaded water this year. Smoothly plugging in Telvent will help ease their concerns.
title: Schneider in smart-grid asset scramble

content: (This article was originally published Thursday.) New Alternatives NALFX, -0.24% mutual fund is in a quandary--when a company in its portfolio becomes too successful, it might have to leave the fold. New Alternatives, which has $251.3 million under management, is the vegan to some other environmentally conscious mutual funds' vegetarianism. The fund invests in more than 30 alternative-energy and related companies world-wide, including power providers that use wind, solar and geothermal energy to turn their generators. But the fund's strict investment criteria dictate that it stay away from companies with even the slightest taint of coal or oil, or may have suspect labor practices. The hydrocarbon taboo is becoming more relevant as more clean-energy businesses are bought by the likes of BP (BP, BP.LN), Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47% and other traditional energy producers. New Alternatives plans to drop two of the more-successful companies in its portfolio--French wind-power and ocean-energy provider EDF Energies Nouvelles SA (EEN.FR) and U.S. solar-cell manufacturer SunPower Corp. SPWRA -- because they were recently acquired by companies with coal and oil assets, a strict no-no for New Alternatives, said fund co-founder and manager David Schoenwald. "It's becoming a problem for us," Schoenwald said. "I'd rather have the companies that were taken over and not the companies that took them over." Still, those companies did well for New Alternatives before being shown the exit. As of Wednesday's market close, SunPower shares were up 66% year-to-date, while those for EDF Energies were up nearly 27%. Currently, the three heaviest companies in the fund are American Water Works Co. AWK, +1.16% at 5.40%, biomass and solar-energy business Abengoa SA (ABG.MC) at 6.37%, and renewable-energy provider EDP Renovaveis SA (EDRVY, EDPR.LB) at 6.59% Alternative-energy investors spooked by Japan's post-earthquake problems with its nuclear plants have shown renewed interest in New Alternatives, which eschews nuclear power as too dangerous, Shoenwald said. Instead of nuclear, the fund prefers natural gas. Nearly 4% of the fund is invested in Northwest Natural Gas NWN, -0.09% an Oregon-based natural-gas distributor that was up 4.4% year over year as of Wednesday's market close. High oil prices have not been such a boon for the fund, however. Most of its holdings are in power utilities, where renewables face off against relatively cheap natural gas and have no real cost advantage. One of the companies still in New Alternatives' portfolio that Shoenwald finds compelling--if not currently successful-- is Ormat Technologies Inc. ORA, -1.36% a Nevada-based business that designs, builds and operates power plants that run off geothermal energy. Problems at Ormat's plant in North Brawley, Calif., helped bring down its first-quarter earnings and caused its stock to plunge more than 25% year-to-date as of Wednesday. But the company remains fundamentally sound and its shares should grow again, Shoenwald said. "I think they can turn it around, but it could take some time," Schoenwald said. Even with that poor performance, the fund is up 12% year-to-date as of Wednesday's market close, according to investment website Morningstar.com, compared to 6% for its World Stock benchmark. The fund's five-year return is 9.3%, lower than the benchmark's 12.3% return. New Alternatives' focus on alternative energy makes it attractive to environmentally conscious investors, Morningstar equities analyst Kathyrn Young said. But being tied to a sector that is subject to the whim of government policy makers, the fund is best suited for investors who don't mind dramatic ups and downs, Young said. "It's a good fund to look at if you are specifically interested in investing in alternative energy," Young said. "But otherwise you might want to think again--it's highly volatile and highly concentrated." More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- General Motors Corp. shares plunged 15% on Wednesday, pushing through levels not seen since the early 1950s after Merrill Lynch warned clients it might be time to bail out on the troubled automaker. GM's GM, +2.45% stock dropped $1.77 to close at $9.98 after Merrill analyst John Murphy slashed his rating on the Dow component to underperform from buy with a price target of $7 a share. He also downgraded several key parts suppliers. "We believe that the pressure on the industry is extreme enough that it is putting the entire automotive value chain at risk, including even once obvious stalwarts," he said. "Large factors are becoming increasingly obvious including declining volumes, deteriorating mix and rising raw materials that are conspiring to compress profits." GM handed in an 18% drop in monthly vehicle sales on Tuesday, sideswiped by plunging consumer confidence and record-high gas prices. The stock moved up slightly on the news as Wall Street had expected an even more severe decline. See full story. Murphy lauded GM's vast restructuring strides but said three factors have combined to "dwarf" the company's best efforts. Topping the list, GM needs to tap the capital markets for up to $15 billion as its cash burn rate goes up with every drop in sales. "Regardless of its structure, however, the bridge financing necessary for the next two years is likely to be larger and more expensive than recognized," Murphy said. Next, he pointed out that the drastic sales declines that have continually rattled the sector will also remain a factor through 2009. Murphy lowered his 2008 light vehicle sales target to 14.3 million cars and trucks from a prior estimate of 14.8 million. "The weakness in demand and deteriorating mix through the first half of 2008 are just the beginning of what is shaping up to be a more severe downturn than even the most bearish industry observers expected," he said. And finally, GM's SUV segment is on the verge of becoming obsolete, eating away at the company's profit potential, he said. A drop in auction pricing provides the clearest evidence that demand has all but dried up completely. Murphy noted that large SUVs aren't even attracting any bids most of the time and many dealers won't even take them as trade-ins. As GM and its competitors continue to struggle, the suppliers that rely heavily on them for their business are feeling the heat. Hence, Murphy cut his rating on Visteon Corp. VC, +2.18% and ArvinMeritor Inc. ARM, +3.57% to underperform and Asbury Automotive Group ABG, +2.97% to neutral. Visteon shares fell 16.7% to end at $2.19 while Asbury lost 11% to close at $11.49. ArvinMeritor initially moved higher after the company gave a bullish outlook for the rest of its fiscal year, citing strong international growth. But the stock succumbed to the broader market pressure and finished down 9.2% at $11.21. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. GT, +0.83% remains Murphy's top pick in the group. The stock closed off 2.7% at $17.55. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Asbury Automotive Group Inc. ABG, +2.97% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $433,000, or a penny per share, down from a year-ago profit of $12.6 million, or 37 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis, the New York provider of automotive retail products and services said it earned $2.4 million, or 7 cents a share, in the latest quarter. Excluding charges related to a debt refinancing and an executive retirement, the company posted earnings from continuing operations of $15.3 million, or 45 cents a share, in the latest quarter. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $2.12 a share for the year. The stock closed Tuesday at $28.24, up 21 cents.

In the year, Thomson earned 55 million euros compared with a loss of 573 million in 2005. Net revenue reached 5.85 billion euros from 5.59 billion, while core-business revenue was 5.74 billion euros against 5.33 billion. Core-business revenue rose 8.3% at constant currencies. "We expect another strong year of revenue growth in our digital and electronic businesses, partially diluted by our physical media businesses," Thomson said in a statement. The firm also announced it has decided to sell its education division as its focus increasingly doesn't fit with its key science, medical and legal divisions. Reed Elsevier added it intends to return any proceeds from the sale to its shareholders through a special distribution. BNP Paribas profit up 29% on investment banking, Italy deal (2:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French bank BNP Paribas(FR:013110)said fourth-quarter net income rose a stronger-than-forecast 29% to 1.72 billion euros ($2.2 billion), with revenue up 25% to 7.05 billion euros. Corporate and investment banking, asset management and the acquisition of Italy's BNL led to the profit rise, the bank said. It's lifting its dividend 19% to 3.10 euros a share. Profit was lower due to a higher tax charge and year-ago gains from the sale of General Mills shares. The firm said a strong performance in North America and international divisions helped drive growth, while profits in Europe held steady. It added it has raised its guidance for organic operating profit growth to 8% for the year. Credit Suisse profit up after Winterthur sale, plans buyback (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss banking group Credit Suisse CS, +1.27% on Thursday beat market expectations by reporting a fourth-quarter net profit of 4.67 billion Swiss francs ($3.74 billion), sharply ahead of the 1.1 billion francs it earned a year ago. The profit included a 1.82 billion francs gain from the sale of its Winterthur insurance business. Fourth quarter revenue rose 42% to 10.81 billion francs. Credit Suisse said growth was driven by its investment banking unit, where revenue rose 63% to 6.09 billion francs in the quarter. Credit Suisse also raised its dividend to 2.24 francs from 2 francs and said it will begin a share buyback program worth up to 8 billion francs over three years. It added the growth prospects for the global economy remain good and it expects client activity levels to remain at around the levels seen in 2006. ING Group 4th-quarter net up 14%; underlying net up 37% (2:17 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- ING Group, ING, +0.06% the Amsterdam banking and insurance group, reported fourth-quarter net income rose 14% and underlying profit advanced 37%, on particular strength in its insurance lines. Earnings were 2.1 billion euros, or 0.98 euro a share, compared with 1.84 billion euros, or 0.85, in the year-earlier period. Underlying net was 2.12 billion euros against 1.55 billion. Underlying profit before tax in insurance rose 31% to 1.34 billion euros while the comparable figure in the banking business advanced 3.4% to 1.16 billion euros. Retail banking showed a 13% profit drop; of the decline, ING said in a statement that "strong volume growth helped offset the impact of flat yield curves." Banks lend at long-term rates and borrow at short-term rates, so when the difference between these rates shrinks, banks' profit margins shrink. ING declared a dividend of 1.32 euros a share, up 12% from 1.18 in 2005. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Asbury Automotive Group ABG, +2.97% Thursday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $12 million, or 35 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $20.5 million, or 62 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis, the New York automotive products retailer said it earnings $15.6 million, or 45 cents a share, in the latest quarter, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $14.4 million, or 44 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $1.38 billion from $1.32 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 38 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the company said it expects earnings from continuing operations of $2.05 to $2.15 a share for fiscal 2007. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $2.03 a share for the year. Asbury's board also authorized the buyback of up to 1.3 million common shares.

content: DULUTH, Ga., Feb. 6, 2018 /PRNewswire/ -- Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. ABG, +2.97% one of the largest automotive retail and service companies in the U.S., reported net income for the fourth quarter 2017 of $42.5 million ($2.03 per diluted share) compared to $67.1 million  ($3.08 per diluted share) in the prior year quarter. It also reported adjusted net income (a non-GAAP measure) for the fourth quarter 2017 of $37.8 million ($1.81 per diluted share) compared to $34.0 million ($1.56 per diluted share) in the prior year quarter, a 16% increase in adjusted earnings per share. Net income for the fourth quarter 2017 was adjusted for a $5.1 million pre-tax loss for franchise rights impairments ($0.15 per diluted share) and a $7.9 million benefit ($0.37 per diluted share) related to adjustments to deferred tax balances as a result of recent changes to the tax law. Net income for the fourth quarter 2016 was adjusted for a $45.5 million pre-tax gain on divestitures ($1.30 per diluted share); $6.6 million pre-tax legal settlements benefit ($0.19 per diluted share); $0.5 million pre-tax real estate related impairment charges ($0.01 per diluted share); and $0.9 million benefit from discrete tax items ($0.04 per diluted share). As a result of recent changes to the tax law, we expect our effective tax rate to be between 25% and 26% in 2018, which is down from our prior guidance of approximately 38%. "We closed out 2017 with a strong performance delivering 16% adjusted EPS growth in the quarter," said David Hult, Asbury's President and Chief Executive Officer. "During 2017, in a declining SAAR environment, we expanded our dealership footprint, returned approximately $35 million of capital to our shareholders, maintained our industry leading operating margins, and grew adjusted EPS 6%.  This performance is a direct result of our team's hard work, dedication, and commitment to continuous improvement. Going forward, we will continue to execute our two-part strategy: drive operational excellence and deploy capital to its highest returns." Fourth Quarter 2017 Operational Summary Same store (a non-GAAP measure): Total revenue flat; gross profit increased 2% New vehicle revenue increased 2%; gross profit decreased 3% Used vehicle retail revenue decreased 6%; gross profit decreased 10% Finance and insurance revenue and gross profit increased 6% Parts and service revenue increased 3%; gross profit increased 2% Total store: SG&A as a percentage of gross profit decreased 200 basis points to 67.3% Adjusted income from operations (a non-GAAP measure) as a percentage of revenue was 4.7% Adjusted diluted EPS (a non-GAAP measure) increased 16%      Acquisition Update: In January 2018, we acquired a Honda franchise in Indianapolis, Indiana For the full year 2017, the Company reported net income of $139.1 million ($6.62 per diluted share) compared to $167.2 million ($7.40 per diluted share) in the prior year period. Adjusted net income (a non-GAAP measure) for 2017 was $135.1 million ($6.43 per diluted share) compared to $137.3 million ($6.08 per diluted share) in the prior year period, a 6% increase in adjusted EPS. Additional commentary regarding the fourth quarter and full-year results will be provided during the earnings conference call on February 6, 2018 at 10:00 a.m.  The conference call will be simulcast live on the internet and can be accessed at www.asburyauto.com or www.ccbn.com.  A replay will be available at these sites for 30 days. In addition, a live audio of the call will be accessible to the public by calling (800) 239-9838 (domestic), or (323) 794-2551 (international); passcode - 2155173.  Callers should dial in approximately 5 to 10 minutes before the call begins. A conference call replay will be available two hours following the call for seven days, and can be accessed by calling (888) 203-1112 (domestic), or (719) 457-0820 (international); passcode - 2155173. About Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. ("Asbury"), a Fortune 500 company headquartered in Duluth, GA, is one of the largest automotive retailers in the U.S.  Asbury currently operates 81 dealerships, consisting of 95 franchises, representing 29 domestic and foreign brands of vehicles.  Asbury also operates 24 collision repair centers.  Asbury offers customers an extensive range of automotive products and services, including new and used vehicle sales and related financing and insurance, vehicle maintenance and repair services, replacement parts and service contracts. content: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan 09, 2018 (BUSINESS WIRE) -- The Presidio Group advised the ownership of Terry Lee Companies, Inc. in the sale of the Honda dealership in Avon, Indiana, west of Indianapolis, to Asbury Automotive Group, Inc., the owner of 94 retail automotive franchises in the U.S. including ten Honda franchises and Hare Chevrolet in the Indianapolis market area. Terry Lee Honda will be renamed Hare Honda. The transaction involving the Honda dealership was completed January 8, 2018. Terms were not disclosed. “I am very pleased with the result and timing of this transaction. I am confident that Asbury is truly the right buyer for our employees and our customers,” said Terry Lee, Owner of Terry Lee Honda. Mr. Lee has over 40 years of automotive retail experience in the Midwest, beginning his career at age 21 in Indianapolis before moving to Cincinnati, Ohio to open Terry Lee Chevrolet. He returned home to the Indianapolis market area in 2008 to open Terry Lee Honda, which has consistently won the Honda President’s Award, been on the Top 100 Automotive News Best Dealerships to Work For list, and received the Indianapolis Star Top Workplaces Award as one of the top 75 employers in Indiana for six years in a row. In 2014, Terry Lee started Terry Lee Crossing, a 72-acre commercial real estate development on Highway 37, just ten minutes north of Indianapolis in Noblesville. In 2015, he built new dealerships for the Genesis and Hyundai franchises with room for five more manufacturers or other commercial properties. This will now be his primary focus. “The Presidio Group provided excellent representation and ran a thorough and confidential process,” Mr. Lee continued. “Asbury is very happy with this acquisition as it further expands our footprint in this great market. Terry Lee Honda is a well-run operation with a great reputation,” said David Hult, President and Chief Executive Officer of Asbury. “We look forward to further success in the Indianapolis market with Hare Honda and with Hare Chevrolet.” “Presidio is honored to have assisted in bringing this transaction together,” said Brodie Cobb. Mr. Cobb is Founder and CEO of The Presidio Group, which advised Mr. Lee in the sale of the Honda dealership. “Terry Lee is an excellent dealer who has worked hard over the years to earn the dealership’s stellar reputation. This transaction is evidence that buyers are still actively looking for quality franchises.” Geoffrey Grodner and Dustin Plummer of Mallor Grodner LLP served as legal counsel to Terry Lee Companies. Kevin Sutton and Katherine Frazier of Hill Ward Henderson served as legal counsel to Asbury. The Presidio Group provided M&A advisory services to Terry Lee Companies through its wholly-owned investment bank, Presidio Merchant Partners LLC. About The Presidio Group LLC. The Presidio Group LLC is an independent merchant banking firm focused on investment banking and principal investing. The firm was founded in 1997 with the simple mission to relentlessly put the interests of clients first. By steadfastly adhering to this philosophy, the firm has earned the trust of clients throughout the United States. To date, Presidio has closed 59 dealership transactions worth more than $3.7 billion and is a leader in the automotive retail sector. The Presidio Group focuses on dealership transactions over $50 million in value. They also publish Presidio’s Where the Rubber Meets the Road, a leading source of information for automotive retailers on corporate finance and M&A activity, and speak at numerous industry conferences. The Presidio Group is based in San Francisco. Presidio Merchant Partners LLC is a subsidiary of The Presidio Group LLC and is a member of FINRA and SIPC. content: DULUTH, Ga., Oct. 24, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. ABG, +2.97% one of the largest automotive retail and service companies in the U.S., reported net income for the third quarter 2017 of $30.7 million, or $1.48 per diluted share. During the quarter, we had two non-recurring events that negatively impacted our results.  First, our dealerships in Florida, Georgia, and Houston, Texas had various levels of business interruption due to Hurricanes Irma and Harvey. We believe the net impact of the hurricanes was a reduction in earnings of at least $0.10 per diluted share.  Second, the CEO transition announced in August resulted in an accounting charge of $0.05 per diluted share. We did not adjust our earnings for the above events. "Our team did an outstanding job managing through the tragic storms that we experienced this quarter.  Due to their efforts we were able to limit the storms' impact on our business," said Craig Monaghan, Asbury's President and Chief Executive Officer. content: DULUTH, Ga., Aug. 22, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- The Board of Directors of Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. ABG, +2.97% ("Asbury" or the "Company"), one of the largest automotive retail and service companies in the U.S., today announced that Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer David W. Hult will succeed Craig T. Monaghan as the Company's President and Chief Executive Officer effective January 1, 2018.  Mr. Hult, who has served as Asbury's Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer since November 2014, will also join the Company's Board of Directors.  Mr. Hult has over 30 years of extensive automotive retail experience and has held senior management positions with both large public and private automotive retail organizations, including RLJ McLarty Landers Automotive Holdings, Group 1 Automotive and Penske Automotive Group. Under the planned succession, and in furtherance of the Company's long-term strategic goals, effective January 1, 2018, Mr. Monaghan will become Vice Chairman of the Board until the date of the Company's 2018 annual meeting of stockholders.  Mr. Monaghan also will serve as a non-executive Special Advisor to the Company until his retirement on April 30, 2019. "We are thankful to Craig for his dedication to Asbury since originally joining the Company in 2008," said Thomas C. DeLoach, Jr., the Chairman of the Board. "Craig is responsible for significant growth and value creation at the Company, and we appreciate his willingness to continue to serve Asbury in a transitional role following his retirement as President and CEO.  David has already contributed greatly to the growth of the Company, and the Board is unanimous in its belief that David is the ideal next chief executive for Asbury." Mr. Monaghan added, "I am delighted that the Board has promoted David to President and CEO of the Company.  I look forward to continuing to work with him to execute Asbury's business strategy and deliver long-term value to stockholders and other stakeholders." Mr. Hult stated, "I am excited to lead the Company and our 8,000 associates and look forward to driving further growth for the Company.  I want to thank the Board of Directors of the Company for providing me this opportunity.  Craig has served as a wonderful mentor since I joined the Company. I look forward to his continued advice and counsel as we work to ensure a smooth and successful transition." About Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. Mr. Goodman also served in various roles at The Home Depot, Inc. ("Home Depot") from February 2006 to April 2011, including Director of Strategic Business Development and Director of Finance responsible for financial leadership of the Home Services Division, and Financial Planning and Analysis for Home Depot. Before joining Home Depot, he held various capital markets, finance, strategy accounting and treasury positions with Morgan Stanley, Inc. in London, England and Deloitte & Touche LLP in New York. Income from continuing operations for the first quarter 2016 was adjusted for $3.4 million of pre-tax real estate related charges, or $0.09 per diluted share. See attached reconciliation for reported adjustments related to both of these periods. Total revenue for the first quarter remained flat at $1.6 billion compared to the prior year period; total revenue on a same-store basis (a non-GAAP measure) was up 3% from the prior year period. "Our ability to drive incremental used sales, enhance F&I PVR, and grow parts and service enabled us to deliver same-store gross profit growth of 3% and industry leading operating margins of 4.6%," said Asbury's Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, David Hult. Further, management assesses the organic growth of our revenue and gross profit on a same store basis. We believe that our assessment on a same store basis represents an important indicator of comparative financial performance and provides relevant information to assess our performance at our existing locations. Same store amounts consist of information from dealerships for identical months in each comparative period, commencing with the first month we owned the dealership. Additionally, amounts related to divested dealerships are excluded from each comparative period. Non-GAAP measures do not have definitions under GAAP and may be defined differently by and not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies. As a result, any non-GAAP financial measures considered and evaluated by management are reviewed in conjunction with a review of the most directly comparable measures calculated in accordance with GAAP. Management cautions investors not to place undue reliance on such non-GAAP measures, but also to consider them with the most directly comparable GAAP measures. In their evaluation of results from time to time, management excludes items that do not arise directly from core operations, or are otherwise of an unusual or non-recurring nature. Because these non-core, unusual or non-recurring charges and gains materially affect Asbury's financial condition or results in the specific period in which they are recognized, management also evaluates, and makes resource allocation and performance evaluation decisions based on, the related non-GAAP measures excluding such items.  In addition to using such non-GAAP measures to evaluate results in a specific period, management believes that such measures may provide more complete and consistent comparisons of operational performance on a period-over-period historical basis and a better indication of expected future trends. Management discloses these non-GAAP measures, and the related reconciliations, because it believes investors use these metrics in evaluating longer-term period-over-period performance, and to allow investors to better understand and evaluate the information used by management to assess operating performance. title: Asbury Automotive Group Announces First Quarter 2017 Financial Results

content: DULUTH, Ga., March 29, 2017 /PRNewswire/ -- Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. ABG, +2.97% one of the largest automotive retail and service companies in the U.S., announced that it will release its first quarter financial results before the market opens on April 27, 2017. Asbury senior management will host a conference call later that day, at 10:00 a.m. Eastern Time. The conference call will be simulcast live on the internet and can be accessed by logging onto www.asburyauto.com or www.ccbn.com. A replay will be available at these sites for 30 days. In addition, a live audio of the call will be accessible to the public by calling (877) 852-6579 (domestic), or (719) 325-4929 (international); passcode –1223221. Callers should dial in approximately 5 to 10 minutes before the call begins.  A conference call replay will be available two hours following the call for seven days, and can be accessed by calling (888) 203-1112 (domestic), or (719) 457-0820 (international); passcode – 1223221. About Asbury Automotive Group Asbury Automotive Group, Inc. ("Asbury"), a Fortune 500 company headquartered in Duluth, GA, is one of the largest automotive retailers in the U.S. Asbury currently operates 80 dealerships, consisting of 96 franchises, representing 29 domestic and foreign brands of vehicles. Asbury also operates 24 collision repair centers and 2 stand-alone used vehicle stores. Asbury offers customers an extensive range of automotive products and services, including new and used vehicle sales and related financing and insurance, vehicle maintenance and repair services, replacement parts and service contracts.
